awd_titl_txt: Impact of Perlecan Mimics on Cartilage Pericellular Matrix Biomechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
Osteoarthritis, which results from the degradation of the articular cartilage, is a condition that affects a significant portion of the population in the US, with increasing occurrence as individuals age.  The pericellular matrix, a structure that surrounds cartilage cells (chondrocytes), has been shown to transmit information about mechanical loading in cartilage to the cells.  If proteoglycans, a type of macromolecule, in the pericellular matrix degrade, this can lead to early onset osteoarthritis.  However, the precise role of these macromolecules in the mechanical properties and response of articular cartilage is unknown.  This project will use a molecule that mimics the behavior of an important proteoglycan molecule, perlecan, to determine its effect on the mechanical behavior and response of chondrocytes, the pericellular matrix, and the extracellular matrix.  By increasing knowledge in this area, new directions of investigation will be opened up regarding cartilage degeneration and potential therapies to minimize the impact of osteoarthritis.  The research team will involve undergraduates and underrepresented students in the research as well as participate in STEM summer camps that support the Philadelphia K12 community.

This project is organized around three objectives.  First, the diffusion kinetics and distribution of perlecan mimics will be confirmed in normal and osteoarthritic human articular cartilage.  Second, the in situ nanomechanical behavior of the chondrocyte, pericellular matrix, and extracellular matrix will be determined using Atomic Force Microscopy for both normal and osteoarthritic articular cartilage, both in the presence and absence of the perlecan mimics.  Finally, the molecular interactions of the perlecan mimics with naturally occurring pericellular and extracellular matrix biomolecules will be determined.  An improved understanding of the role of perlecan in articular cartilage response could lead to the ability to engineer the pericellular matrix or extracellular matrix to support tissue regeneration and as an augmentation to cellular tissue engineering.  The techniques developed in this study for articular cartilage will be appropriate for other musculoskeletal tissues as well as other soft tissues that are compromised through degeneration and aging, such as the skin or urethra.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common cause of disability in older adults, afflicting an estimated 10-15% of adults aged over 60. Successful regeneration of degraded OA cartilage has been challenged by our limited capability of recapitulating the biomechanical and biophysical cross-talk between the extracellular matrix (ECM) and chondrocytes. This renders the pericellular matrix (PCM), the proteoglycan-rich, immediate chondrocyte microniche, an emerging target for modulating chondrocyte mechanotransduction in both healthy and OA cartilage. In OA, degeneration of residing proteoglycans in the PCM is a leading event of disease initiation, which leads to disrupted chondrocyte mechanotransduction, contributing to an imbalance in cellular anabolic-catabolic processes and irreversible breakdown of the tissue. The objective of this project was to elucidate biomechanical behavior of the mechanobiological transducer, the PCM, in human adult normal and OA articular cartilage explants through a novel method by introducing our proteoglycan mimic into the PCM.

With the support of this NSF grant, we discovered that biomimetic proteoglycans (BPGs) have the capability to molecularly engineer cartilage PCM and ECM through molecular adhesive interactions with the local micro-environment. We showed that BPGs can infiltrate throughout the full thickness of osteochondral bovine cartilage explants during ex vivo culture. This localization of BPGs in the PCM resulted in increased PCM micromodulus and enhanced chondrocyte intracellular calcium signaling. Applying molecular force spectroscopy, we revealed that BPGs integrate with native PCM through augmenting the molecular adhesion of aggrecan, the major PCM proteoglycan, at the nanoscale. These interactions are enabled by the biomimetic “bottle-brush” ultrastructure of BPGs and facilitate the integration of BPGs within the PCM. Thus, we demonstrated that BPGs can be used for modulating molecular interactions of pericellular proteoglycans and harnessing cell mechanosensing. Additionally, we found similar localization of BPGs in the PCM of both healthy and mild-OA cartilage specimens from human donors. As such, BPGs also augmented the micromechanics of PCM in both normal and degenerated human tissues, demonstrating the translational potential of BPGs for OA intervention in a minimally invasive manner. Furthermore, these findings of BPG-driven augmentation of the native cellular microniche can extend beyond the scope of cartilage engineering, as the PCM is a feature of multiple cell and tissue types.

This award has broader impacts in education and outreach. Two Ph.D. candidates and two Masters students at Drexel University have been trained while working on this project. In this process, special efforts have been made to recruit and retain students from underrepresented groups in engineering, including women and minorities. The research findings of this project have been incorporated in the curricula at Drexel University and benefit both undergraduate and graduate teaching. This includes the supervising of undergraduate teams for their senior design projects to design new engineering products for biomechanics research as the capstone of their undergraduate education. In addition, the PI has collaborated with inner-city high schools of Philadelphia to provide annual science workshops to increase the students' enthusiasm in a STEM career, and has participated in Drexel's BIOMED Summer Academy to engage high school students in a strategically chosen curriculum activities during summer break. The results from the project have also been broadly disseminated to the academic community and general public through journal publications, meetings, conferences, and social media.

 


Last Modified: 02/24/2023
Modified by: Lin Han
